image.altText: A man in a suit on a laptop searching real estate websites.

props.synopsis: More people looking to break into the property market are lying on their loan applications in desperation to try to secure a home loan, according to new data. The struggle to refinance is also getting harder with more interest rate rises in 2024 possible.

title.children: 'People can be very creative': Inside the rise of 'liar loans' in Australia's property market

image.altText: Justice Gregory Geason looks off camera.

props.synopsis: Press freedom advocates have condemned a Tasmanian court’s decision to bar journalists from attending the hearing of Justice Gregory Geason, who faced court on Friday charged with assault and emotional abuse charges.

title.children: A judge was charged with assault, but the media was barred from court. Advocates are 'deeply troubled'

image.altText: A young girl with pigtails plays on the sand at the beach.

props.synopsis: An ACT Coroner's Court inquest is considering mistakes made by Canberra Hospital staff that delayed the diagnosis of five-year-old Canberra girl Rozalia Spadafora before her death.

title.children: 'Do not have time to go back': Triage nurse defends not taking 5yo Rozalia Spadafora's blood pressure before her death

image.altText: People walking past a Westpac sign.

props.synopsis: Westpac apologises for the time taken to resolve the issue, which left some of its customers "experiencing issues" accessing their accounts due to an online outage.

title.children: Westpac announces services restored after thousands of customers were unable to access funds overnight

image.altText: A male politician next to a picture of a female politician.

props.synopsis: Canberra Liberals member Jeremy Hanson loses the deputy leadership of the party to opposition health spokeswoman Leanne Castley.

title.children: 'Watch us shine': Leanne Castley installed as Canberra Liberals' deputy leader after Jeremy Hanson dumped

image.altText: Traffic on the road heading towards Balmain in sydney

props.synopsis: Sydney drivers are promised road works set to start tonight will bring some relief at the problem-plagued "spaghetti junction", but some experts say the project was fundamentally flawed.

title.children: 'Clear it would be a disaster': Sydney's Rozelle Interchange issues will be ongoing, road experts say

image.altText: A man stands on a balcony of an apartment that looks over a suburban area.

props.synopsis: When the Carrigans decided to embrace high-rise living, they didn't expect it to be so hard to find a family-sized apartment.

title.children: Families are looking to embrace Sydney's high-density future. But a big-enough unit will cost them $1.3m

image.altText: Mary Lloyd with her daughter.

props.synopsis: Four years after being diagnosed with a form of breast cancer that's hard to detect, ABC journalist Mary Lloyd goes back to her doctors to find out how women can look out for it.

title.children: The sneaky breast cancer I almost missed — and how other women can look out for it

image.altText: Two female soldiers inspect a drone

props.synopsis: This is hardly the first time a military institution has dismissed the capacity of a potential adversary with catastrophic outcomes. And it is not the first time for Israel, writes Mick Ryan.

title.children: Israel may have known about Hamas's plan to attack a year ago. But it's not the first time it has misjudged a threat

image.altText: Palestinians look at the destruction by the Israeli bombardment of the Gaza Strip.

props.synopsis: As Israel strikes continue throughout Gaza, human rights organisations say babies were left to die in Al-Nasr hospital after shelling took place.

title.children: Rights groups say babies left to die in bombed hospitals as Gaza faces Israel's widening ground offensive

image.altText: A man cutting stone for a kitchen benchtop

props.synopsis: New research shows silica isn't the only component in engineered stone products that's a cause for concern with researchers finding higher metal content in alternative products can also damage the lungs.

title.children: 'Not just about silica': Study finds alternatives to engineered stone bench tops may not be safe

image.altText: Tim Barrett speaking at an event in military dress

props.synopsis: The navy removed a requirement for "value for money" from the tender process for its $45 billion future frigate program, with previously secret documents also revealing the Department of Defence selected a controversial British warship design despite being aware of potential risks.

title.children: Previously secret report raises doubts about $45 billion Defence program

image.altText: Composite image of Xi Jinping, Anthony Albanese and Joe Biden.

props.synopsis: The dust has barely settled after Australia and China reached an uneasy truce, but our abundance of critical minerals and China's stranglehold on them has us in the middle of a geopolitical tug of war between America and the Middle Kingdom, writes Ian Verrender.

title.children: Caught in the crossfire: Can Australia straddle the east west divide?

image.altText: Beverley Wang, with shoulder length black hair, black shirt and slight smile, looks at camera, against a blurred background.

props.synopsis: From strange intimacy to the thrill of the unpredictable, radio offers something no other form of media can match.

title.children: Drunk guests, strange intimacy and profound trust: What's behind our love affair with radio?

image.altText: A newbon baby asleep in a hospital bed

props.synopsis: Tina thought she would never see her baby son again after her health deteriorated eight years after a double lung transplant. But behind the scenes, her medical team were thinking "outside the box".

title.children: Tina never thought she would be the 'dying mum of a five-day-old'. Months later, her life 'really is a fairytale'

image.altText: Primary aged school stduents with school logo green backpacks walk along a city street

props.synopsis: It's that time of year when it seems the more school fees parents pay, the less time their children spend in school. Why the differences?

title.children: Why do private schools get more holidays than public schools?

image.altText: An elderly couple stand in front of their motor home

props.synopsis: Mal and Maggie Butcher have spent years on the road after selling their house. While they love their camper, ill health has slowed them down and they have no permanent site options without drawing the ire of local council.

title.children: Grey nomad couple with nowhere to go call for council compassion on backyard camping

image.altText: Mam in suit speaking on podium, with smile

props.synopsis: The agreement is expected to focus heavily on Papua New Guinea's internal security, with PNG looking to Australia to do more to help train and bolster its police force.

title.children: Australia and Papua New Guinea poised to sign major bilateral security agreement

image.altText: A medium photo of a middle-aged man with receding hair and beard, wearing a singlet and glasses

props.synopsis: A man released from immigration detention as a result of a recent High Court ruling is charged with two counts of indecent assault.

title.children: Man released from immigration detention after High Court ruling charged with indecent assault

image.altText: A man with scruffy hair squints while taking a selfie in bushland.

props.synopsis: Albert Thorn was "at the heart" of the savage assault and murder of Bradley Lyons in 2018. He will be nearing 90 by the time he is eligible for parole.

title.children: Vigilante who kidnapped, tortured and executed Victorian dad sentenced to life behind bars

image.altText: A tugboat motors past a massive cargo ship.

props.synopsis: Between 2,000 and 3,000 litres of bilge water containing sulphur and other waste was dumped into the ocean near Esperance in 2020. The company that owns the ship and its captain could face hefty penalties.

title.children: Chinese bulk carrier officer 'absent-minded' when he dumped waste off WA coast, court hears

image.altText: Mount Marapi volcano spews a huge thick grey cloud of volcanic ash into a grey sky.

props.synopsis: Rescuers find more survivors and recover bodies but further search efforts are suspended after another small eruption at Mount Marapi, which has been active since January.

title.children: Climbers killed, survivors found after Indonesian volcano erupts

image.altText: Family of five standing together wearing matching red shirts with a Cockayne Syndrome logo on the front.

props.synopsis: The National Disability Insurance Scheme lost an estimated $1.4 billion through "payment errors" including fraud and over-claiming last financial year, a five-fold increase from two years ago.

title.children: 'Billion dollars down the drain': Families feel the loss of NDIS fraud and error ahead of review

image.altText: An elderly Indigenous man and woman standing side-by-side out the front of their home.

props.synopsis: Residents of a community in north-east Arnhem Land say they had no access to running water across three days and received no communication about when the outage would be fixed.

title.children: 'Like a nightmare': NT remote community without water for three days amid severe heat

image.altText: A woman waters her garden.

props.synopsis: The corporation says the increases could equal a $71 a year increase over the next four years, but are required to maintain service standards and meet its expenditure requirements.

title.children: SA Water seeks to increase water bills 3.5 per cent above inflation in latest business plan

image.altText: A young girl with pigtails plays on the sand at the beach.

props.synopsis: An ACT Coroner's Court inquest is considering mistakes made by Canberra Hospital staff that delayed the diagnosis of five-year-old Canberra girl Rozalia Spadafora before her death.

title.children: 'Do not have time to go back': Triage nurse defends not taking 5yo Rozalia Spadafora's blood pressure before her death

image.altText: Map of Queensland and the Coral Sea showing possible cyclone paths.

props.synopsis: The BOM says a tropical low over the Solomon Islands is likely to develop into a severe storm that might head our way.

title.children: Potential cyclone brewing over Coral Sea could cross Australian coast

image.altText: Penny Wong shakes hands with French Foreign Minister Catherine Colonna in Canberra.

props.synopsis: Both countries want to reset relationships that soured when Australia ditched a lucrative multi-billion-dollar submarine contract with the French company Naval Group so it could join AUKUS.

title.children: Australia strengthens regional defence ties with France with both countries keen to move on from AUKUS controversy

image.altText: Workers on a construction zone.

props.synopsis: On the eve of the Victorian government's signing of a multi-billion-dollar contract for Melbourne's Suburban Rail Loop, experts are calling for Australia's biggest and most expensive infrastructure project to be scrapped.

title.children: 'A lot of dollars, not a lot of benefit': Experts call for Suburban Rail Loop to be scrapped

image.altText: A man with a wreath on his head stands on a podium with a medal

props.synopsis: A magistrate refuses bail for Olympic rowing silver medallist Simon Burgess who has been charged with domestic violence offences in Tasmania.

title.children: Olympic rower in custody on domestic violence charges after magistrate refuses bail

image.altText: North Korea's leader Kim Jong Un applauds at the 5th National Meeting of Mothers in Pyongyang.

props.synopsis: The United Nations Population Fund estimates that as of 2023 the fertility rate, or the average number of children being born to a woman in North Korea, stood at 1.8.

title.children: Kim Jong Un pushes for baby boom in address to North Korean mothers

image.altText: A collage of images: A microphone, and four live gigs, including a woman singing and a man sitting and playing guitar

props.synopsis: From Perth to Albury, we take a look at Australia's live music scene and how it's faring after a pandemic and during a cost of living crisis.

title.children: 'We can't force people to drink': As patrons tighten their belts, Australia's live music scene struggles to stay afloat
